articles.headline: Congress Votes to Override Obama Veto on 9/11 Victims Bill
articles.snippet: Both chambers overwhelmingly voted on Wednesday for a bill that would let Americans sue Saudi Arabia in the attacks — the first veto override of the Obama presidency.
articles.abstract: Both chambers overwhelmingly voted on Wednesday for a bill that would let Americans sue Saudi Arabia in the attacks — the first veto override of the Obama presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congress on Wednesday voted overwhelmingly to override a veto by President Obama for the first time, passing into law a bill that would allow the families of those killed in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks to sue Saudi Arabia for any role in the plot.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer, Mark Mazzetti and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: California Suspends Ties With Wells Fargo
articles.snippet: The state will drop several relationships with the bank, which is enmeshed in a scandal over the creation of millions of unauthorized accounts.
articles.abstract: The state will drop several relationships with the bank, which is enmeshed in a scandal over the creation of millions of unauthorized accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Citing Wells Fargo’s “venal abuse of its customers,” the California treasurer took the unusual step on Wednesday of suspending many of its ties with the San Francisco bank as it continues to reel from the scandal over the creation of as many as two million unauthorized bank and credit card accounts.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Win Back Young Voters From Third Parties
articles.snippet: More than a third of voters ages 18 to 29 say they will vote for a third-party candidate, and when asked to choose a major-party nominee, 10 percent said they would not vote.
articles.abstract: More than a third of voters ages 18 to 29 say they will vote for a third-party candidate, and when asked to choose a major-party nominee, 10 percent said they would not vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: With just six weeks to go until Election Day, younger voters are shunning the two major political parties on a scale not seen since Ross Perot’s third-party bid for the presidency in 1992, a striking swing in public opinion that is slicing into Hillary Clinton’s thin margin for error.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Yamiche Alcindor

articles.headline: U.S. Just Made It a Lot Less Difficult to Sue Nursing Homes
articles.snippet: The decision, by the Department of Health and Human Services, would restore the right to legal action to 1.5 million nursing home residents.
articles.abstract: The decision, by the Department of Health and Human Services, would restore the right to legal action to 1.5 million nursing home residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal agency that controls more than $1 trillion in Medicare and Medicaid funding has moved to prevent nursing homes from forcing claims of elder abuse, sexual harassment and even wrongful death into the private system of justice known as arbitration.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Coachella Classic: A Festival for Rock Giants and Their Aging Fans
articles.snippet: Desert Trip will feature the likes of Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and Neil Young, tickets top out at $1,600 and it may never be staged again.
articles.abstract: Desert Trip will feature the likes of Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and Neil Young, tickets top out at $1,600 and it may never be staged again.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day in February, Paul Tollett, the promoter of the Coachella music festival, was summoned to Mick Jagger’s dressing room in Buenos Aires.

articles.headline: Deutsche Bank Is the Darling of the Short-Sellers
articles.snippet: By the numbers, Deutsche Bank is solid. But its legal battles, its thin cash cushion and its risk appetite have undermined its stock.
articles.abstract: By the numbers, Deutsche Bank is solid. But its legal battles, its thin cash cushion and its risk appetite have undermined its stock.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a market full of crowded trades, few have become as fashionable as the bet that Deutsche Bank’s stock price will keep on falling.

articles.headline: Torn Over Donald Trump and Cut Off by Culture Wars, Evangelicals Despair
articles.snippet: In small-town Iowa, conservative Christians say they feel abandoned, with no true champion in the presidential race and a country that they believe has turned its back.
articles.abstract: In small-town Iowa, conservative Christians say they feel abandoned, with no true champion in the presidential race and a country that they believe has turned its back.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRIMES, Iowa — Betty and Dick Odgaard used to own the tiny church next door to their home. They had built it over 13 years into an art gallery, bistro, flower shop and framing service. They even rented out the chapel, with its bright stained glass windows, for social events.

articles.headline: In Letter, Redstones Urge Viacom and CBS to Explore Merger
articles.snippet: The media mogul Sumner Redstone and his daughter, Shari Redstone, are suggesting an all-stock transaction that would leave them firmly in control.
articles.abstract: The media mogul Sumner Redstone and his daughter, Shari Redstone, are suggesting an all-stock transaction that would leave them firmly in control.
